subject-link: BAR6303WE6327HTSA1 Reasons for unstable forward current？
truncated-body: Parts:BAR6303WE6327HTSA, What is the reason for the instability of forward current?When supplying DC through a regulated power supply alone, it was fo...
full-body: Parts:BAR6303WE6327HTSA, What is the reason for the instability of forward current?When supplying DC through a regulated power supply alone, it was found that the current was suddenly high and unstable.We originally used the BAP70-03W parts （D2~D6， All 5）for this circuit, but later the BAP70-03W parts was discontinued and replaced with your company's model. Perhaps the substitute we are looking for does not match. Is there any other model that your company can replace the BAP70-03W parts? Could you please recommend it to us? Thank you.

subject-link: Designing an RF power clamp using diodes
truncated-body:
Hi,
I am trying to design a simple circuit that is using diodes to clamp RF power at 26dBm. Currently i am utilizing a TVS diode (ESD101-B1-02 Series)...
full-body: Hi,
full-body 2: I am trying to design a simple circuit that is using diodes to clamp RF power at 26dBm. Currently i am utilizing a TVS diode (ESD101-B1-02 Series) shunted to ground for this. Based on my understanding, a TVS diode shunted to ground should clamp at the Maximum Working Voltage (Vrwm) and ESD101-B1-02 series has Vrwm of +/- 5.5V. So using the Power to voltage conversion table, a Vp of 5.5 should clamp at around 25dBm. However , when i used a signal generator to pump ++26dBm to it, i noticed that it doesn't clamp at 25dBm. I think my understanding is wrong and maybe it's the clamping voltage that i should refer to ? Appreciate help on this.
full-body 3: Also, what would be the best way to utilise diodes for RF power clamps at 26dBm. Would stacking multiple anti-parallel diodes work?
